title: 110_s2455
content:
The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title. Additional emergency CDBG funding is addressed in the Act. The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" authorizes $1 billion for assistance to States, cities, and counties for housing foreclosure impacts and rental assistance for individual renters. Counseling services are exempt from the funding limitation. The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" authorizes $1 billion for housing foreclosure impacts and rental assistance for individual renters. Funds cannot be directly given to homeowners for foreclosure prevention purposes, except for counseling services. Certified housing counseling services approved by the Secretary of Housing can receive the grant amounts. The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" authorizes $1 billion for housing foreclosure impacts and rental assistance for individual renters. Funds can be provided directly to certified housing counseling services approved by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 3. INCREASED PUBLIC SERVICES REQUIREMENT CAP.

    The Act increases the public services requirement cap from 15% to 25% for funds appropriated under this Act.

SEC. 4. LOW AND MODERATE INCOME REQUIREMENT.

    At least 50% of the funds under this Act must benefit low- and moderate-income individuals.

SEC. 5. PLANS AND REPORTS. SEC. 5. PLANS AND REPORTS.

    States, metropolitan cities, or urban counties must submit a comprehensive plan for fund usage and quarterly reports to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive provisions of statutes or regulations to facilitate the use of funds, excluding fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and environmental requirements. Waivers must align with the overall purpose of the statute. Additionally, the Secretary may waive the 50 percent low and moderate income requirement upon request from a State, metropolitan city, or urban county. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive requirements for the use of funds if it aligns with the statute's purpose. Waivers may include the 50 percent low and moderate income requirement and the public service requirement cap, granted upon request from a State, metropolitan city, or urban county. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive the public service requirement cap upon request from a State, metropolitan city, or urban county if a compelling need is demonstrated. Waivers must be published in the Federal Register at least 5 days before taking effect and reviewed every 2 years for reauthorization. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can grant waivers for the public service requirement cap, which must be reviewed and reauthorized every 2 years. The Secretary must notify the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations of any waivers granted or denied at least 5 days before the decision. SEC. 7. Noncompliance with community development requirements under this Act will be subject to the provisions of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. SEC. 8. The Comptroller General will conduct an audit of all funds appropriated under this Act and submit a report to the Senate and House Committees. SEC. 9. Reports will be required as part of the oversight process. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must provide quarterly reports to the Senate and House Committees on the use of funds, outcomes of assistance activities, certified housing counseling services, steps taken to prevent fraud and abuse.
